discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
RMAN does not support backup and recovery of the change-tracking file itself.
If the whole database or a subset needs to be restored and recovered, then recovery has no user-visible effect on change tracking. After the restore and recovery, the change tracking file is cleared, and starts recording block changes again. The next incremental backup after any recovery is able to use change-tracking data.

questions.question_text:
To enable faster incremental backups, you enabled block change tracking for the database.
Which two statements are true about the block change tracking file? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The database clears the change tracking file and starts tracking changes again, after whole database restore and recovery operations.
choices.A: Multiple change tracking files can be created for a database.
choices.C: RMAN does not support backup and recovery of the change tracking file.
choices.B: The change tracking file must be created after the first level 0 backup.

questions.answer_description:
AB: You can make individual table columns invisible. Any generic access of a table does not show the invisible columns in the table. For example, the following operations do not display invisible columns in the output:
* SELECT * FROM statements in SQL
* DESCRIBE commands in SQL*Plus
* %ROWTYPE attribute declarations in PL/SQL
* Describes in Oracle Call Interface (OCI)
Incorrect:
Not D: You can make invisible columns visible.
You can make a column invisible during table creation or when you add a column to a table, and you can later alter the table to make the same column visible.
References:

choices.A: The %ROWTYPE attribute declarations in PL/SQL to access a row will not display the invisible column in the output.
choices.E: A primary key constraint can be added on the invisible column.
choices.B: The DESCRIBE commands in SQL *Plus will not display the invisible column in the output.
choices.C: Referential integrity constraint cannot be set on the invisible column.
choices.D: The invisible column cannot be made visible and can only be marked as unused.

discussion.content:
a,b,e correction
12C New Feature : Invisible Columns (Doc ID 1566790.1)

a,d,e

discussion.content: Why is not E?

comments.content:
E is wrong, you have to run the scripts manually:

With the new Pre-Upgrade Information Tool, the default behavior of the prerequisite upgrade checks has been enhanced in the following ways:

A log file, preupgrade.log, is created containing the output of the Pre-Upgrade Information Tool.

The preupgrade_fixups.sql script is created to list and describe issues that can be fixed using SQL*Plus in the source database. It also attempts to resolve trivial issues when you execute it.

The postupgrade_fixups.sql script is created to address issues that can be fixed after the database has been upgraded. See Chapter 4, "Post-Upgrade Tasks for Oracle Database."

discussion.content:
BCD
Any invalid SYS or SYSTEM objects found before upgrading the database are stored in the table named registry$sys_inv_objs after running the Pre-Upgrade Information TooL
Evaluate Dependencies and Add ACLs for Network Utility Packages 
The Pre-Upgrade Information Tool displays any deprecated parameters and desupported parameters it finds in the Deprecated Parameters and Desupported Parameters sections, respectively.

Hi, checking this question, one option is missing:
F. The postupgrade_fixups.sql script is created to address issues that can be fixed after a database has been upgraded.

The correct answers are BCF
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/UPGRD/preup.htm#UPGRD52880

A is wrong
E is wrong, BCD is correct

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the Pre-Upgrade Information Tool? (Choose three.)

choices.A: It clears all user recycle bins in a database and releases their storage space.
choices.C: It evaluates the dependencies of network utility packages.
choices.E: It generates fix-up scripts and automatically runs them to resolve issues that are flagged in the source database.
choices.B: It writes a list of invalid SYS and SYSTEM object to the registry$sys_inv_objs table.
choices.D: It identifies any deprecated and unsupported parameters.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/upgrd/checklists-for-oracle-database-upgrade.html#GUID-2DB48303-DC1E-41CD-831D-864D76BD8061

Use this checklist to prepare your server with the earlier Oracle Database release before you start the upgrade:
Clean up the database: Empty the recycle bin,Check for INVALID objects in SYS and SYSTEM, Check for duplicate objects in SYS and SYSTEM
Gather dictionary statistics: To decrease Oracle Database downtime, gather optimizer statistics.

Selected Answer: DE
I would definitely choose D,E
A- just not correct
B- while this can be done it is not an action that MUST be done prior to beginning in upgrade. You will have to do this again post-upgrade anyway as best practice
C- definitely wrong. You set this parameter post-upgrade. Even then, it is best practice not to set this parameter immediately after an upgrade but for some time after. Waiting to set it ensures we can downgrade to our previous version if needed in case of an error.
D- Oracle doc states this as a task to complete before an upgrade
E- same as above 

https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/upgrd/database-preparation-tasks-to-complete-before-upgrades.html#GUID-58C1A4B9-32F4-44E5-B82B-5D0EC78A6AE2
